title: Advertisers Are Wary of Breaking Up Google and Facebook
summary: Several marketers at the annual ad festival in Cannes say they enjoy benefits from digital ad behemoths but want more information-sharing. CANNES, France-Advertisers have griped about the power Google and Facebook Inc. wield over the digital ad market. But they are generally wary of breaking up the tech giants, judging by the views of the attendees at the annual advertising festival held here on the French Riviera.

title: House GOP Leader Wants a Data- Privacy Law
summary: Bipartisan support for regulation of Google and Facebook grows after strict California rules passed. WASHINGTON-House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy backed the idea of national legislation to safeguard consumers' data privacy, adding a prominent GOP voice to the bipartisan support in Congress for tackling how technology companies amass and use their information.

title: Millions of Business Listings on Google Maps Are Fake-and Google Profits
summary: Resume Subscription. Out of habit, Nancy Carter, a retired federal employee, turned to Google for help one August evening. She ended the night wishing she hadn't.

title: Marathon Petroleum's Former CFO Back in Role
summary: Current finance chief is moving to replace the head of subsidiary Speedway LLC, who plans to retire. Marathon Petroleum Corp. on Thursday said Donald Templin would return to the role of finance chief as part of a broader executive restructuring at the oil refiner.

title: Oregon Governor Dispatches Police to Find GOP Legislators
summary: Seeking to deny a quorum on cap-and-trade legislation, Republican state senators flee. Oregon's Democratic governor has sent the state police in search of the entire GOP Senate delegation, who left the state and went into hiding Thursday in an effort to stop a cap-and-trade bill to address climate change from passing.

title: High Court Rules That 40-Foot Cross Can Remain on Public Land
summary: Justices Ginsburg and Sotomayor dissented, arguing that by maintaining the cross, the state places Christianity above other faiths. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court voted 7-2 Thursday to let a 40-foot cross remain on a Maryland traffic island, concluding that the memorial to World War I's fallen holds a secular meaning that comports with the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: AICPA Proposes Overhaul of Evidence Standards in Private-Company Audits
summary: New standards would better define the role of new technologies in gathering information, including from social media and data analytics. The auditing standards board of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants on Thursday proposed an overhaul of the rules governing audit evidence for private companies to better define the role of new technologies in audits.

title: Investors Are Buying More of the Housing Market Than Ever Before
summary: Their interest poses a challenge for millennials and other first-time buyers. The share of investor purchases of U.S. homes have climbed to an all-time high, a sign that rising home prices have done little to dampen demand for flipping homes or turning them into single-family rentals.

title: UnitedHealth Agrees to Buy Payments Firm Equian
summary: It is likely UnitedHealth would merge Equian into its Optum health-services arm. UnitedHealth Group Inc. has agreed to buy health-care payments firm Equian LLC from its private-equity owner for about $3.2 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Aurelius Warns Frontier Communications Against Chapter 11
summary: Hedge-fund manager said Frontier should instead pursue a multibillion-dollar debt swap. Aurelius Capital Management LP is lobbying the board of Frontier Communications Corp. against putting the financially strained telecommunications giant into chapter 11 bankruptcy.

title: Floating Classroom Teaches New York City Students About Sea Life
summary: Eighth-graders test the waters of Jamaica Bay; horseshoe crabs elicit screams. Khadiza Rahman grew up a few miles from New York City's Jamaica Bay but hadn't heard of it until a recent class trip brought her out on the water. She and fellow students at P.S. 122 in Astoria, Queens, were aboard the R/V CUNY 1, a custom-made hybrid boat that has been turned into a floating classroom.

title: Quadriga Founder Spent Client Money, Monitor Says
summary: Ernst & Young says Gerald Cotten, late founder of defunct Canadian cryptocurrency exchange, funneled client money into fraudulent accounts. The court-appointed monitor for bankrupt QuadrigaCX said the Canadian cryptocurrency exchange's late founder took most of the money entrusted to him by clients and spent much of it on himself and his wife.

title: Slack Shares Jump in Trading Debut
summary: Messaging service's stock opens above reference price, trends higher through the afternoon. Slack Technologies Inc. surged in its trading debut on the New York Stock Exchange, the latest technology firm to jump into a hot initial-public-offering market.

title: Gun Stocks Tick Up Amid Political Uncertainty
summary: Shares of gun makers had been hard hit by the gun-friendly policies of the Trump administration. Gun makers, on a losing streak since the election of Donald Trump in 2016, could be starting to recalibrate.

title: Justices Liberate a Public Cross
summary: A step toward reviving the proper meaning of the Establishment Clause.. The original meaning of the First Amendment is making a comeback on the Supreme Court. The latest evidence is Thursday's rousing 7-2 ruling in support of religious liberty and pluralism in the public square.

title: Nevada Embraces Public Unions
summary: Democrats let state employees collectively bargain. Watch out for a state income tax.. Nevada taxpayers had a good 54-year run, but this month their luck ran out. The state Legislature recently overrode a 1965 ban on collectively bargaining for state employees. Gov. Steve Sisolak has signed the bill, and watch now for a tax-and-spend ratchet to accelerate in one of the nine states without a tax on wage and salary income.

title: Joe Biden's Race-Card Education
summary: He preaches political civility, and the left says he's soft on segregation.. Joe Biden isn't a conservative but he's learning what it feels like to be one. On Tuesday night at a fundraiser in Manhattan he made comments that no reasonable person would interpret as racially insensitive-and was immediately censured by his Democratic competitors as though he had defended Jim Crow.

title: With Slack's Buzzy IPO, Email Takes Another Hit
summary: CIOs take notice as the workplace collaboration startup makes its Wall Street debut. Slack Technologies Inc.'s highflying trading debut Thursday reflects the rapid growth of cloud-enabled workplace collaboration tools, which are driving a shift from individual to group productivity, according to chief information officers, tech-firm executives and analysts.

title: Investors Dodge Global Worries in Currencies of Egypt, Ukraine
summary: The exotic currencies are among top performers in a market dogged by dollar strength and growth fears. Investors are snapping up exotic currencies such as the Egyptian pound and Ukrainian hryvnia as they seek assets with little correlation to global markets amid rising worries over growth and trade.

title: Time for Tough Love With Turkey
summary: Erdogan's purchase of Russia's S-400 crosses a NATO red line.. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has spent 15 years chipping away at his country's reputation as a stalwart Western ally. Now Turkey's deepening military ties with Russia are a breaking point that should prompt Washington to re-evaluate its broader relationship with Ankara.

title: Make America Even Greater
summary: To win re-election, Trump needs a bold second-term agenda. Here are some ideas.. At one point in his Tuesday re-election launch in Orlando, Fla., President Trump polled the audience: Run again on "Make America Great Again"? Or switch the slogan to "Keep America Great"? A roaring crowd opted for the latter.

title: Understanding Ukraine's Jewish President
summary: He plays down his ethnic roots, stressing national and political identities instead.. Kiev, Ukraine

title: How Masterpiece Cakeshop Fell Short
summary: Lower courts are still taking a cramped approach to claims of artistic freedom.. It's been a year since the U.S. Supreme Court announced its 7-2 ruling in favor of Masterpiece Cakeshop owner Jack Phillips, whom Colorado officials tried to put out of business because of his conscientious objection to same-sex marriage.

title: Liberalism Isn't What It Used to Be
summary: The values that made me a supporter of RFK in 1968 put me at odds with today's progressives.. In the late spring of 1968, when I was 26, I helped organize Robert F. Kennedy's presidential campaign in the Bronx. I rented a storefront headquarters, recruited a team of volunteers, and held a launch event at the old Concourse Plaza Hotel-all to prepare for the candidate's expected appearance in New York following his victory in California. That, tragically, wasn't to be. Instead, I took my turn in the honor guard that surrounded the senator's casket throughout the night in St. Patrick's Cathedral, and attended his funeral June 8.

title: Justice Department Moves to Block Printer Deal
summary: Quad/Graphics Inc.'s proposed acquisition of LSC Communications Inc. would unite two, large magazine-and-catalog printing companies.. Federal regulators want to block the combination of two, large U.S. magazine-and-catalog printers on concerns the deal could raise costs for publishers, retailers and consumers.

title: My Sister, My Uncle and Trump
summary: They loved him and were sure he'd win. I couldn't share their jolliness, but I respected their rebellion.. It was four years ago this week, June 16, 2015, and a great professional gift was given me. I had just watched Donald Trump's announcement speech and was pondering its impact. This guy isn't going to be president; we've been reading about his tabloid antics for 30 years. But he'll have some impact, some support. Who? How much?

title: A British Warning for the Trump Fed
summary: Monetary policy is a poor substitute for the supply-side reforms the president can't or won't undertake.. There's a rumor going around that President Trump likes low interest rates-at least when the Federal Reserve imposes them. The latest hint comes via a characteristically subtle tweet this week in which Mr. Trump harangued Europe for potentially planing to ease rates (and implicitly demanded Fed Chairman Jerome Powell do so).

title: What Does Beijing Want With Your Medical Records?
summary: The 2015 Anthem hack raises chilling questions about surveillance within America's borders.. Why would China steal the personal medical information of nearly 80 million Americans? That's been the question since the Justice Department unsealed an indictment of two Chinese nationals for the 2015 hacking attack on Anthem, the health-care giant.

title: 'The Plaza' Review: Potemkin Village on the Park
summary: Walk past the Plaza at night these days and you'll see most of the windows are dark, its apartments belonging to absentee owners.. Enrico Caruso was none too pleased. The renowned tenor had just moved into New York's newly opened Plaza Hotel-where the modern amenities in every room included thermostats, telephones and centrally synchronized clocks-and his vocal training was being interrupted by the loud ticking of the timepiece in his suite. He dispatched it with an angry blow, and in so doing damaged the hotel's entire system. Guests slept late or missed their luncheon engagements and eventually descended in an irate body to hound the front desk.

title: Prosecutors Say Roger Stone Violated Gag Order
summary: Trial judge is asked to examine Instagram posts related to Russian interference in 2016 election. WASHINGTON-Prosecutors on Thursday asked a federal judge to examine whether longtime Trump adviser Roger Stone violated a judicial order barring him from commenting about matters involving the Russia investigation and his own criminal trial.

title: U.S. Women Beat Sweden 2-0 to Wrap Up Group Stage
summary: The Americans face Spain on Monday in the round of 16. LE HAVRE, France-The signs were mildly menacing for the U.S. women's soccer team's World Cup game Thursday against Sweden. Swedish players had spoken of the U.S. looking past the game. Both teams had already qualified for the round of 16. Yellow-and-blue-clad fans filled large sections of Stade Océane at a tournament where U.S. fans have overwhelmed others.

title: Walmart to Pay $282 Million to Settle Claims of Corrupt Payments Abroad
summary: Claims were related to payments to outside consultants in Brazil, China, India and Mexico. Walmart Inc. agreed to pay $282 million to resolve yearslong criminal and regulatory investigations into whether it paid bribes around the world, agreeing that it had lax policies in place to catch potential corruption.

title: Expedia's Trivago Is Sued Over Seized Cuban Hotel
summary: The lawsuit is the latest filed under a provision of the Helms-Burton Act that was activated last month. Two U.S. citizens sued hotel-search company Trivago NV under a newly revived provision of a U.S. law that permits legal action by U.S. citizens or entities against companies doing business on property that was confiscated by the Cuban government.

title: Gold Surges to Highest Price Since 2013 After Fed Hints at Rate Cut
summary: Industrial metals also rally as bets on lower borrowing costs weaken the dollar. Metal prices shot up Thursday, lifted by a weaker dollar, after the Federal Reserve suggested it was willing to lower interest rates in the coming months.

title: New York Lawmakers Give Veterans More Leeway to Qualify for FDNY
summary: A bill will increase from six to seven the number of years veterans can subtract from their age to qualify to work for the department. Amid intense debates on minimum wage, rent regulations and pot legalization, one piece of legislation united New York lawmakers this session.

title: Blame Brexit for Carnival's Sinking Shares
summary: Cruise operator's stock falls more than 7% after surprise earnings warning. Cruise operator Carnival Corp. was the worst performer in the S&P 500 on Thursday.

title: PayPal's Operating Chief to Leave Company
summary: COO Bill Ready is latest of several senior leaders to depart within past year. PayPal Holdings Inc. said Bill Ready, one of its top executives, is leaving the financial-technology company at the end of the year.

title: New Play Looks at 'Bonacker' Fishermen of Long Island
summary: Their challenges, traditions, culture and even dialect are explored. Some may recall the 1990 Billy Joel song "The Downeaster 'Alexa,'" which chronicled the struggles of Long Island's fishermen during a period when they faced increased regulations and other hardships. As Mr. Joel sang, "There ain't much future for a man who works the sea."

title: S&P 500 Hits Record Close After Fed Hints of Interest-Rate Cut
summary: Dollar weakens and bond yields drop, while commodities prices jump. The S&P 500 surged to its first record close since April, underscoring confidence on Wall Street that the U.S. economy and global markets remain healthy despite a fresh tumble in bond yields around the world.

title: Court Allows Rules Blocking Family-Planning Funds for Abortion Providers
summary: Planned Parenthood will be most affected, though court order isn't the final word. A federal appeals court on Thursday said the Trump administration can implement new rules prohibiting federal family-planning grants to health clinics offering on-site abortions or referrals for the procedure.

title: National Rifle Association Suspends Second-Highest Executive
summary: In lawsuit, group accuses Chris W. Cox of taking part in conspiracy to oust CEO Wayne LaPierre. The infighting at the National Rifle Association intensified Thursday, as the gun-rights group suspended its second-highest official and accused him of participating in an alleged coup attempt in April against Chief Executive Wayne LaPierre.

title: Trump to Issue Executive Order on Health-Care Price Transparency
summary: The president on Monday will call for insurers and doctors to disclose new details about the cost of care, a move that industry groups have resisted. President Trump plans to issue an executive order Monday to compel the disclosure of prices in health care, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: U.S. Companies Brought Home More Profits From Overseas
summary: Firms repatriated $776.51 billion in foreign profits last year following tax-law overhaul, $111 billion more than previously reported. WASHINGTON-U.S. companies brought home more foreign profits in the first year after the tax-law overhaul than the government previously estimated.

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Reject Governor's Millionaire's Tax
summary: Democratic-controlled legislature passes $38.7 billion budget; for wealthiest, income taxes wouldn't rise. New Jersey lawmakers approved a $38.7 billion budget that doesn't raise taxes on millionaires, in the latest rift between Gov. Phil Murphy and his fellow Democrats.

title: Sears Retirees Win Committee Status Over Insurance Termination
summary: Company terminated life insurance plan earlier this year, saying it couldn't afford $1.3 million monthly expense. The judge overseeing Sears Holdings Corp.'s bankruptcy gave a green light for company retirees to form an official committee that will advocate for the life-insurance benefits Sears recently terminated.

title: Nissan, Renault to Partner With Waymo on Driverless Cars
summary: Alliance partners to explore driverless car options in their home markets of France and Japan. Renault SA and its alliance partner Nissan Motor Co. have signed a deal with Alphabet Inc.'s self-driving technology unit Waymo to jointly explore driverless car options in their home markets of France and Japan.

title: 'Toy Story 4' Review: Once Again, With Joy and Deep Feeling
summary: Woody, Buzz and other familiar faces return-joined by new animated friends-in a story that deals with nothing less than the purpose of life.. It's been almost a quarter-century since the toys in "Toy Story" first captivated us, then took up permanent residence in our hearts. The trilogy that came to a stirring climax nine years ago was complete, emotionally as well as dramatically, so the advent of "Toy Story 4" raises questions: Did we need a new installment; did it turn out to be worth doing; and what, if anything, does it add to a canon that's become a national treasure? The answers are no, not necessarily; yes, absolutely; and much more than anyone might have guessed. The new film isn't flawless, but it's hugely enjoyable and speaks, with bewitching buoyancy, to nothing less than the purpose of living and the mystery of life.

title: 'Wild Rose': Redemption Song
summary: A Scottish country singer tries to rebuild her life and make it to Nashville after being released from jail.. From the first moment the camera finds her in "Wild Rose"-literally the first moment in the first scene-Jessie Buckley lights up the screen, and the light doesn't diminish, even when the story strains credulity. Given her luminescence, and the lovely country music she gets to sing in her own lovely voice, my credulity didn't mind being strained at all. It went wherever she sent it, which is a fair description of what star quality can do.

title: 'Toni Morrison: The Pieces I Am' Review: An Infectious Spirit
summary: Timothy Greenfield-Sanders's documentary studies the Nobel Laureate as a working writer and editor as well as a celebrated author.. The ultimate test of "Toni Morrison: The Pieces I Am," a documentary feature by Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, is whether it makes you want to read, or re-read, its subject's books. The film certainly does that. It also makes you feel that you know her well enough. Not well, in any private sense-she speaks about her divided self, about one of the people she is remaining inside her, "the one who doesn't do documentaries." Still, the one who does do documentaries is awfully good at it, an irrepressible spirit who can tell the most harrowing stories-or toss off witty lines-with a look-you-in-the eye style that brooks no casual listening.

title: Carnival Lowers Profit Forecast on Cuba Travel Ban, Slower Europe Demand
summary: Carnival's shares, along with those of its rivals, sink on the news. The world's biggest cruise operator, Carnival Corp. , cut its full-year earnings outlook, citing a hit from voyage cancellations, the abrupt Cuba travel ban and weakening demand in Europe.

title: Roy Moore to Make Second Senate Bid in Alabama
summary: The former Alabama chief justice lost a 2017 special election for the Senate to Democrat Doug Jones. Republican Roy Moore-who narrowly lost to Democrat Doug Jones in a 2017 special election for the U.S. Senate in Alabama-announced on Thursday he will make another run.

title: Middle East Clashes Send Oil Sharply Higher
summary: Crude futures rise more than 5% after Iran said it had shot down a U.S. drone. Oil prices climbed sharply Thursday as tensions mounted in the Middle East and the dollar fell, extending a period of high volatility for crude.

title: 'Little Women' Review: Subtext Becomes Text
summary: Kate Hamill's lively new adaptation of the classic novel draws out the sexual ambiguities that have always been just beneath the story's surface.. New York

title: Darden Shares Still Offer Bang for the Buck
summary: Owner of Olive Garden and other restaurants still looks attractive, despite mixed results. Despite a mixed update for investors, the owner of Olive Garden is still a well-oiled machine.

title: Kroger Seeks Patience As It Works to Reshape Business
summary: Shares of nation's biggest supermarket operator fell 12% over past 12 months. Kroger Co. executives are seeking patience from investors as they continue to oversee efforts to transform the business while facing heightened competition from a range of food retailers and shifting shopping patterns.

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended June 15
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Donald Trump and the New York Times
summary: Will the President and the newspaper's employees stop accusing each other of treason?. This column has been hoping for a few years that the discourse conducted by the President of the United States would always remain above that occurring in the pages of the New York Times. But such hopes seem unlikely to be fulfilled any time soon.

title: 10-Year Treasury Yield Falls Below 2%, Defying Expectations
summary: Yields at multiyear lows reflect the difficulties central bankers face in normalizing monetary policy after a decade of unusually easy money.

title: New York Protects Its Tenants and Lawyers
summary: The truth is free-market policies have failed many New Yorkers, particularly low-income residents for whom the city has been anything but "livable" over the past two decades.. Your editorial "Albany Goes Wild" (June 14) recycles the same old landlord versus tenant arguments in its gripes about New York's recently enacted rent regulations.

title: Tax Credits Generally Fail to Achieve Goals
summary: The winners from economic-development subsidies are frequently the companies on the receiving end, publicity-seeking politicians and the consultants who broker the deals, and that's about it.. News that the Wisconsin Economic Development Corp. subsidized jobs created outside of the Badger State and businesses that actually reduced employment isn't surprising ("Wisconsin Tax Credits Fail To Hit Job Pledge, Audit Says," U.S. News, June 12). The winners from economic-development subsidies are frequently the companies on the receiving end, publicity-seeking politicians and the consultants who broker the deals, and that's about it. The losers encompass nearly everyone else, including most taxpayers and other businesses that pay for the deals through higher taxes or by receiving worse government services.

title: Time For a Major FCC Spectrum-Use Reform
summary: Spectrum "dezoning" would be the biggest and most socially beneficial act of regulatory reform since the abolition of airline price and entry controls in the 1970s.. Holman W. Jenkins, Jr. is right that an FCC auction to transfer underused "C-band" spectrum from satellite links to 5G mobile broadband would be better than letting that spectrum languish ("How Government Can Get Brave About Spectrum," Business World, June 15). But the "snarl" in shifting spectrum to more valuable uses is entirely an artifact of the FCC's limiting spectrum licenses to particular uses, which it thinks important at the time but that invariably become obsolete as technology and markets progress.

title: The Lexus UX 250h: Perfect If You Have No Kids and Extra Cash
summary: This tiny 'crossover-ette' won't win any races down at the track, but it's speedy in the city, an ideal urban car, says Dan Neil. I GET LOVE LETTERS all the time. They are not addressed to me but to some long-lost companion of the road, a car or truck that meant the world to somebody. These beloved specimens usually fall into one of several categories: daddy's hot rod (which go into the larger daddy issues mailbag), the family wagon, the faithful companion, the jewel box.

title: Supreme Court Will Review Puerto Rico Board Appointments
summary: Justices take up constitutional challenge to board overseeing bankrupt U.S. territory's finances. The U.S. Supreme Court took up a constitutional challenge to the board overseeing Puerto Rico's finances, a development that could upset years of work on the bankrupt U.S. territory's economy.

title: McDonald's Tests Robot Fryers and Voice-Activated Drive-Throughs
summary: Burger giant wants to speed service as competition for fast-food diners mounts. McDonald's Corp. is designing voice-activated drive-throughs and robotic deep-fryers as the burger giant works to streamline its menu and operations to speed up service.

title: Philadelphia Takes Officers Off Street Over Racist Social-Media Posts
summary: St. Louis prosecutor bars officers from testifying in court; other cities investigating offensive material. The Philadelphia Police Department put 72 officers on desk duty and a St. Louis prosecutor barred 22 officers from testifying in court, following allegations that law-enforcement officers in those and other U.S. cities posted racist or otherwise offensive comments on social media.

title: 'Years and Years' Review: A Slapdash Dystopia
summary: HBO's painfully unfunny new series imagines the chaos of the political near-future.. After a cacophonous summing-up, episode 1 of the English series "Years and Years" finally collapses with a character screaming "What happens now!?" Viewers may well be answering, "Who bloody well cares?" And why is that? The reasons are instructional, actually, given all that goes on in the show while still managing to turn one off.

title: 'Robert Shaw-Man of Many Voices' Review: A Chorus of Affection
summary: The new PBS documentary tells the often-complicated life story of the conductor, featuring many of those who performed under his baton.. Doing its duty as an "American Masters" presentation, "Robert Shaw-Man of Many Voices" makes quite clear that Shaw was a master-most famously as a director of choral music, one who raised its standards, honed its performances and raised its status in the classical world. But he was also distinctly American, in the rustic, up-by-the bootstraps sense: He shouldn't have succeeded, but did. When his Collegiate Chorale sang the final movement of Beethoven's Ninth with the NBC Orchestra in 1948, Arturo Toscanini (notoriously exacting about everything, but especially the Ninth) said of Shaw, "I have found the maestro I have been looking for."

title: Manhattan Developer Sells His Downtown Penthouse for $33 Million
summary: Steven Witkoff sells his condo at 150 Charles Street, a high-profile building in the West Village.. New York real-estate developer Steven Witkoff has sold his personal penthouse in Manhattan's West Village for $33 million, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Trump Says Downing of U.S. Drone May Have Been Unintentional
summary: Iran shot down a U.S. military drone amid tensions in the Middle East. President Trump suggested Iran's downing of a U.S. military drone was unintentional and triggered by someone "loose and stupid," providing at least momentary relief from the potential threat of a military confrontation in the Persian Gulf.

title: Fed Gives Lift to Corporate Bonds
summary: Central bank's latest messaging is turning out well for corporate borrowers and the investors that buy their bonds. The Federal Reserve's latest messaging is turning out well for corporate borrowers and the investors that buy their bonds.

title: Political-News Sites Forge Ad Group to Compete With Facebook, Google
summary: Digital News Alliance combines left-leaning, conservative and centrist publishers. Political advertising makes strange bedfellows.

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Pass Bill to Extend Corporate Tax Incentives
summary: Move comes after governor said he would veto such legislation. The New Jersey legislature passed a temporary extension of the state's tax-incentive programs, ignoring a veto threat by Gov. Phil Murphy.

title: Is This the Sportiest Rolex Yet?
summary: With its sleek, monochromatic black palette and rubber-bound band, the Yacht-Master 42 looks ready for SoulCycle class. ROLEX, THE HOUSEHOLD name of Swiss watchmakers, rarely deviates from the original design DNA of its midcentury status watches like the Submariner and the Daytona. However, look into the sleek, dark face of the brand's new Yacht-Master 42 and you'll see traces of contemporary streetwear glinting back at you. "Because [the Yacht-Master is] one of Rolex's newer models...it occupies this space within their offerings that allows them to experiment," explained New York-based Ryan Chong, a watch specialist for auction house Christie's. First released in 1992, the original Yacht-Master and its subsequent renditions have run the gamut of "guilty pleasure" finishes (think: mother-of-pearl dials, even gem-set bezels), and have been seen on flashy-watch fans like Brad Pitt and Ellen DeGeneres.

title: Geyer Had a Humility More Journalists Should Emulate
summary: "I reject the idea that journalists are messengers of the truth. It's arrogant. I think journalism is a search for the little relative truths that at best keep us relatively sane.". Thank you for David Satter's remembrance of Georgie Anne Geyer ("A Pioneer Who Witnessed Revolutions," op-ed, June 11). I did a sabbatical research project several years ago and traveled around the country to interview several nationally syndicated columnists. Ms. Geyer graciously welcomed me into her Chicago home. The most memorable quote she made was, "I reject the idea that journalists are messengers of the truth. It's arrogant. I think journalism is a search for the little relative truths that at best keep us relatively sane."

title: Humanism Isn't Always the Only or Best Way to Help
summary: C.S. Lewis held that we humans are actually souls with bodies, not the other way around. Perhaps that should not be such an alien outlook among those offering services to hurting children.. Regarding Naomi Schaefer Riley's "Christians Are Pro-Life After Birth, Too" (Houses of Worship, June 14): It is well to note that Christians are extending pro-life endeavors to those abused and neglected children who struggle with life after birth. I have been a court-appointed special advocate for such kids for a decade-and all the state and private social-work organizations, by rules or ethos, are strictly secular humanist (at least up here in the Northeast, as Ms. Riley alludes to).

title: Trump to Award Medal of Freedom to Racing Team Owner Roger Penske
summary: President called racing mogul 'a great gentleman'. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Thursday that he will award the Presidential Medal of Freedom to auto racing mogul Roger Penske.

title: The Way We Should Have Been Eating Shrimp All Along
summary: Flash-frying crisps up the shell so deliciously, there's no need for peeling. Just eat the whole thing, head, tail and all. This recipe includes a tangy chile-lime dipping sauce and a side of wilted greens with crunchy garlic chips. HEAD, SHELL, TAIL and all: That's how Christina Nguyen likes to eat fried shrimp. "Frying gives it a cracker-like exterior that's really tasty," she said.

title: Gold's Run Signals Worrying Future
summary: The Federal Reserve's easing signals have given gold a boost, but the move portends economic troubles. Gold has taken the lead. The asset, at times considered a haven, has hit an almost six-year high after the Federal Reserve signaled that it was willing to lower interest rates. If rates continue to fall, expect further jumps in the yellow metal. But the moves portend some bad news.

title: Boeing Focuses on Safety, Not Sales, at Paris Air Show
summary: U.S. plane maker seeks to restore its battered reputation after two fatal crashes of its 737 MAX jetliner. LE BOURGET, France- Boeing Co. arrived at the world's largest aerospace extravaganza battling the biggest crisis in its history. It departs having secured a crucial vote of confidence in its beleaguered 737 MAX jetliner and the prospect of further orders on the horizon.

title: Hamas Spurns U.S.-Led Aid Effort
summary: Palestinian group's political leader opens door to investment but rejects any economic plan without a solution to Mideast conflict. GAZA CITY-The Palestinian militant group Hamas signaled it was only open to receiving humanitarian aid generated by a Trump administration peace effort if the assistance is unconditional and doesn't come at the expense of a Palestinian state.

title: Products That Lend a Hand
summary: Home appliances that have made some advances. In the biometrically enhanced domicile of the future, all you will have to do is be yourself and your home will anticipate your every need. Until then, here are some smart appliances designed for high-tech pampering throughout your day:

title: Trump on Fed Decision: 'You Can't Win 'Em All'
summary: President has argued for lower rates and previously suggested he might try to replace Fed chairman. President Trump said he wished the Federal Reserve had cut interest rates at its two-day meeting this week, but added he was encouraged the central bankers seemed ready to deliver rate reductions at coming meetings.

title: Shares of French Bank Natixis Fall on Fund-Liquidity Concerns
summary: Stock fell 12% after Morningstar suspended its rating on fund run by lender's H2O Asset Management arm. Shares of French bank Natixis SA fell 12% Thursday after research firm Morningstar Inc. suspended its rating on a fund run by the bank's H2O Asset Management arm over liquidity concerns.

title: A Bedside Lamp Designed to Help You Sleep Better
summary: Can a sensitive bedside light aid your nightly wind-down and help you wake more peacefully?. I'D LIKE TO THINK I'm good in bed: Sleep comes easily and lasts 8 hours, uninterrupted. But I need optimal conditions: a cool room with a whirring fan and total darkness. Harvard sleep researcher Steven Lockley, a man seemingly after my own heart, found that most lights, whether ultraviolet or artificial, keep us awake by suppressing the body's secretion of melatonin, a hormone that influences circadian rhythms.

title: Boris Johnson Takes Another Step Closer to U.K. Leadership
summary: Johnson, Jeremy Hunt now will take their candidacies to 160,000 members of the Conservative Party during a month-long tour of the country. LONDON-Boris Johnson moved within striking distance of becoming the next British prime minister after Conservative lawmakers Thursday overwhelmingly voted him through to the final round of their leadership contest, raising the prospect of a euroskeptic cheerleader taking the reins of Britain's fraught attempt to quit the European Union.

title: Senate Passes Resolutions Blocking Arms Sales to Saudi Arabia, U.A.E.
summary: The Trump administration approved the sales under rarely used emergency powers to bypass the typical Congressional review process. WASHINGTON-The Senate passed a series of resolutions aimed at blocking 22 arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, dealing another symbolic blow to the Trump administration's close ties to the Middle East allies.

summary: Firms to get initial stress-test results on Friday under eased rules. The Federal Reserve is scheduled to release results of annual stress tests for big banks in two parts, on Friday, June 21, and Thursday, June 27. The firms could have an easier time with the exams because the Fed for this year overhauled several components, including a test of how firms would fare under a hypothetical doomsday scenario. Mark Carney is expected to say Thursday, offering an early insight into how the U.K. central bank will approach the new cryptocurrency.

title: WHO Withdraws Opioid Guidelines
summary: The U.N. health agency cites 'new scientific evidence' as it pulls prescription guidance. The World Health Organization has withdrawn two prescription guidelines for opioid painkillers after U.S. lawmakers alleged the guidance was influenced by the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Forget Old Generals-Highways Can Honor High-Tech
summary: It's about time that BASIC and UNIX got their roadside tributes.. In a classic example of "Why didn't somebody think of that sooner?" the state of New Hampshire has installed an official highway marker honoring "BASIC: The First User-Friendly Computer Programming Language."

title: Erdogan Says Turkey Won't Bow to U.S. Ultimatum Over Russian Missiles
summary: Turkish president threatens to retaliate against any sanctions, says he aims to find solution when he meets with Trump next week. ISTANBUL-President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Thursday that Turkey would retaliate against any U.S. sanctions over its decision to buy advanced air-defense missile systems from Russia, escalating testy rhetoric between the two NATO allies, though he also raised the hope that a solution would be found when he meets with President Trump next week.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Sex-Offender Law in Separation-of-Powers Case
summary: High court says Congress can delegate decisions on certain rules to the executive branch. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a 2006 law designed to crack down on sex offenders, which allowed the U.S. attorney general to decide whether it applies retroactively.

title: Former Interpol Chief Admits to Taking Bribes, Chinese Court Says
summary: Meng Hongwei received more than $2 million in money and goods in return for favors, according to prosecutors. A senior Chinese police official who once headed Interpol admitted to receiving more than $2 million worth of bribes, a trial court said, in a case that symbolized a pitfall in China's growing global reach.

title: Undiscovered Italy: The Strange and Splendid Carso Region
summary: In this string of small towns near the border with Slovenia, you'll find a magnetic mishmash of cultures and culinary attractions from Habsburg-era castles to country taverns where the wine flows freely. THE OLD MAN with the guitar wanted to know if I was married. We had nodded at each other across the courtyard of an outdoor tavern for the past few hours, as the waitress brought out first one jug and then another of housemade Malvasia wine. The strings of his guitar blended with the lowing of cows, the oinking of the odd pig, the neighs of pastured horses. The man and his friends had been singing folk songs-Italian, Slovene, those native to this hinterland in northeastern Italy-since long before sunset. In this hamlet, where my phone regularly picked up Slovenian cell service, language tended to be a mutable thing.

And yet, for all the fervor over single-origin beans from Central America and Africa, third-wave-coffee culture has been slow to embrace Vietnamese product.

title: A House With a Brain
summary: A new class of tech-enabled houses are taking automation to the next level.. In the past decade, home systems that would have recently seemed perfectly Jetsons-esque have flooded the market. title: The Bugs We Can't Live Without
summary: Insect populations are in dramatic decline, and the consequences could be serious for everything from waste management to agriculture. Insects are the little cogs that make the natural world go 'round-and many of these cogs are now in danger of coming loose.
